text: - My name is Chris Niederman.
I'm the general manager

for the global systems
integrator business worldwide.
I've been with AWS for eight years.

I ask everybody when they
join, what was different

than when you thought it would
be than before you joined.
And usually it's people go,

"Wow, the leadership
principles and the culture,
"you guys weren't kidding out that."
And that was probably the biggest epiphany

I had when I joined was
leadership principles,
you run into 'em every single day.

And so the culture is what
makes this a lot of fun.
(upbeat music)

When I travel around the
world, what I love is

that everybody thinks about
leadership principles.

So my first question isn't,
what do you do for a living?
What do you do for a job here?
It's tell me

about your favorite
leadership principle and why.

One of the things I've
discovered is something

that I found is my favorite
leadership principle
has changed over time.

So I could tell you with
certainty in my first 90 days,

and it's generally with
most people, earn trust.

We're not given trust, you
actually have to earn it,
get to meet people and trust each other

in order to really get
the buy-in you need,
help them, and they'll help you.
Customer obsession is absolutely
the number one leadership principle.
It always has been.
If you're not customer obsessed,
maybe it's not the right place for you,
But take customer obsession away,

and there's earn trust,
over time frugality.
It was drilled into my head

what frugality meant
in my third year here,

where I gotten a lot of
investments to build my team

and my manager said, "Hey,
we're not gonna give you

"the investments you
think you need this year.

"Go figure out how to do it
with what we've given you."
I'm like, oh man.
And what I found was it forced me to think

about how to invent and
simplify and think differently

because doing more with less
is the concept of frugality,

and had he not forced
me to think critically
about how to do things differently,
we would not have optimized our team,

and we would not have
had the success we did.
(upbeat music)

At this moment in time when
we're kicking off the year,

we're diving super deep
into our 2022 plans,
our three year vision and so forth,
and we're doing performance reviews,

insist on highest standards is
top of mind for me right now.
That's my favorite leadership principle.
I read a ton of docs every day.

We're not just writing a doc
and trying to do a decision,

or make a decision that
hasn't been well thought out,
we all need to really think through these.
So insisting on high standards
that leads us to be right a lot
while inventing and simplifying.

So it's hard to answer the
question what's my favorite,

'cause they all interweave
and tie so well together,

but they also conflict like
move fast by a fraction,
but take the time to dive deep.
Well, okay, well, which one is it?
It's both.

So there's two new leadership principles

which I am starting to
think more critically about.

You look at scale and success
brings broad responsibility,

and it's a really important
one, and I love that one.
And then you think about the other one

which is striving to be
Earth's best employer.
Striving to be Earth's best employer,

that's not just making
life better for us here,
that's higher and develop the best,

but it's also making sure
that people want to come here.
We wanna be a place that people come
and seek out and can have fun,

a place that they can build,
make an impact and have fun.
I feel obligated

that we can do something
far more than we have.
And somebody once said to me,
"Chris, think about technology

"when we were selling mainframes
back 20, 30 years ago,"
which is one of my earlier jobs at IBM.
It was like, hey, come on, take off work.
Let's go get a beer.
It's not like we're curing cancer.

Somebody said to me when I
first joined here, they said,
"You remember those days?"
"Yeah, I remember those days."

"Think about this, we
actually could cure cancer."
Well, I said, "How do you mean?"
He said,

"We believe that a doctor may
not be the one to cure cancer.

"It could be a data scientist
using AWS technology
"to get more capacity as needed
"to do analytics and insights
"and maybe gene sequencing

"to develop new drugs that
they couldn't do before
"because they didn't have access
"to the right technology or capacity.
"We can provide that."
And so think about that.
If we give the right technology

to the right people, the
right data scientists,
we could cure cancer or Parkinson's,
or come up with new drugs.
The game has changed and given
who we are and what we have access to,

we have a broader responsibility
to the world to help
in a manner that actually changes lives,

whether it's curing a disease
or developing new drugs,
or feeding the world with new analytics

and how we do farming,
and maybe automating that
for more improved crop productions

to double food production
with less resources by 2050.
All of these things are super.

So this is where I begin
thinking about more

about that one about
broader responsibility,
success and scale.
So that at this moment is probably one

of my favorites that I'm
giving a lot of thought to
